messages: 1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b (02:36): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: are you saying that it's impossible for the whatwg to have found the best solutions for a given problem?

41b7b44cc71f6fb087d582d11d943bc3 (02:40): I think he ment that there is always room for improvement.
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (02:42): has anyone argued that there isn't? :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:00): gsnedders: according to my research, about 0.0014% XHTML is served as XML
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:00): (iirc)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:12): is that counting text/html pages with known xhtml doctypes as "xhtml"?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:13): or <html xmlns>?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:15): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, he said "served as XML", so it would seem that it doesn't include text/html pages
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:16): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: he said 0.0014% of "xhtml" is served as xml
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:16): that's just pages served with an XML MIME type, not text/htlm
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:16): what's the rest?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:17): let me rephrase that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:17): it's not 0.0014% of xhtml
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:17): then 0.0014% of xml is xhtml
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:18): I took it as meaning 0.0014% of pages on the web are served as XML
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:19): what is |page on the Web|?
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (03:19): 1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b: I'm saying the attitude that they have the best solution already is what makes people reticent.
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:20): family of XHTML + HTML ? (excluding RSS for example)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:20): that's what I assumed
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:23): awaits clarification

150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (03:29): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: ah, that I can understand. I don't think that is a concern unless people think that "they" are unreasonable and unable to objectively consider different opinions.
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:29): http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/html-wg/20070422#l-225
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:29): big problem with this hack
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:30): because it relies on a lack of strictness of a browser
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (03:30): which means if/when the browser is fixed. the hack doesn't work anymore.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:32): has configured his registry to make application/xhtml+xml equivalent to application/xml, so their hack doesn't work for me
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:34): the page displays in ie but it's treated as generic xml, thus no default styles, no links, no extracted semantics or anything
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:38): that hack of theirs doesn't even work in IE7
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:40): so, if the url ends in .html and there's a <meta charset>, then ie6 will treat it as text/html? correct?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:40): somehow I'm not particularly surpirsed that the XHTML2 WG's conclusion isn't something like "IE doesn't support XHTML, we should provide an HTML alternative", but rather "IE doesn't support XHTML natively, what bugs can we exploit to work around it and maintain our illusion that XHTML can be used on the web?"
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (03:44): can someone translate matthew's last email?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:46): the one that starts with "Dan who?"?

But I don't think it's the greatest example of clear communication
